channel.title: What does this do?
channel.description: I am working on a Tut and i want to be sure of the meaning of something. Does "break;" indicate the end of a case/packet?

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @Darkning Darkning
item.description:
@Darkning wrote:

Ok, so it must be equal or less then the integer argument it is called for. Thanks

Read full topic

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

If you set it to 2, it can still work because that is within the range of Misc.random(2).
If you set it to 3, however, that is 1 above the possible result of the method, so it will not work.

Read full topic

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @Darkning Darkning
item.description:
@Darkning wrote:

So if i would set it to ==2 then it will not work?

Read full topic

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

Actually, [tt]misc.random(int)[/tt] adds 1 to the argument and calls [tt]Math.random()[/tt] which returns a double greater than or equal to 0 and less than 1 which is then multiplied by the new value of the argument.

If the number the method returns is equal to the number on the other side of the operator (which in this case is 1), the result will be true and the code in the if statement will be executed.

Read full topic

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @xpatx xpatx
item.description:
@xpatx wrote:

== means EQUAL to. It means it must equal to 1 or it won’t do what it is called for.

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @xpatx xpatx
item.description:
@xpatx wrote:

It will do a random either being - or +, you cannot tell. You can create a random system that does something like misc.randomAdd(2) so it does the execution like…

teleToX = 4444 + misc.randomAdd(2);

^ That will take the regular X coordinate and either add one or two or none. But you need to create the method for an addition of a random or subtraction.

Read full topic

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

[tt]misc.random(int)[/tt] is a method that returns an integer between 0 and the integer argument it is called with.
So in this case, it could return 0, 1 or 2.

Read full topic

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @Darkning Darkning
item.description:
@Darkning wrote:

Thanks. One other thing.

if (misc.random(2) == 1) { mining[2] = 70; } else { mining[2] = 71; }

I understand the mining[2] part but im not sure about the misc.random. I know that misc.random will do something such as toX = 1111+misc.random(2); will move it - or + 2 to 1111. Im just not sure how it is used here.

Read full topic

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @xpatx xpatx
item.description:
@xpatx wrote:

Break means the end of a case. The reason you add a break is because if you don’t it will overflow. So, yes it means the end of a case in a switch statement.

[code=java]
public void example(int i)
switch(i) {

case 1: //Works
System.out.println(“This is a message that case one is being outputted on data.”);
break;

case 2: //Fails
System out.println(“This is case two.”);

case 3: //Works
System.out.println(“This is case three”);
break;

}[/code]

Case 2 and 3 would cause an error because case 2 needs to return something, which would be the execution the case needs. So basically, the break causes it from stop overflowing.

Read full topic

item.title: What does this do?
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

The break keyword ends a loop or switch statement.
